text: One of the following plays is based on the mistakes of a night

options.A: The Gods are not to Blame

explanation: She Stoops to Conquer, a comedy by Oliver Goldsmith, is based on a series of misunderstandings and mistaken identities that occur over the course of a single night. The protagonist, Kate, pretends to be a maid to win the affection of the man she loves, leading to comedic situations driven by confusion and mistaken assumptions.

text: The genres of Literature are
explanation:
These are the three main genres of literature.
Proserefers to ordinary written or spoken language without a structured meter, including novels, short stories, essays, etc.Poetryis a genre that uses verse and meter, often employing figurative language, rhyme and rhythm.Dramarefers to works intended for performance on stage and involving dialogue and acting.

text: A seemingly absurd statement is a/an
explanation:
Aparadoxis a seemingly absurd or self-contradictory statement that, upon closer inspection, may reveal an underlying truth. It challenges conventional thinking and highlights the complexity or irony of a situation.
For example, the statement "less is more" is a paradox because it seems contradictory, yet it may have a deeper meaning.

text: A play is watched by a/an
explanation: Aplayis watched by anaudience, which refers to the group of people who gather to view and enjoy a theatrical performance.

text: Poetry differs from prose by its use of
explanation: Poetry differs from prose in its use ofcondensed language. It uses more concise, figurative and compact language to convey deeper meanings, emotions and ideas in fewer words.

text: Pick out the odd item
explanation: Actors, stage and dialogue are all elements related todrama, whilechaptersare associated withproseornovels, not drama.

text: A piece of writing about oneself is a/an
explanation: Anautobiographyis a piece of writing in which an author writes about their own life.

text: A short poem expressing intense emotions and usually sung is a/an
explanation: Alyricis a short poem that expresses intense emotions written in the first person and is set to music or sung.

text: Pick out the odd item

options.A: The Gods are not to Blame

explanation: This is because"The Gods Are Not to Blame"by Ola Rotimi is a play, while the other options,"The Concubine"(Elechi Amadi),"Things Fall Apart"(Chinua Achebe), and"The African Child"(Camara Laye), are novels.

text: In ''Biodun did his best but was first from behind'', "first from behind'' is an example of
explanation: The phrase "first from behind" is a paradox because it combines two contradictory ideas. "First" means being at the front or ahead, while "behind" suggests being at the back. The juxtaposition of these opposites creates a paradox, which is a statement that appears self-contradictory but may contain an element of truth.

text: A literary work that ridicules ideas or the follies of people is a/an
explanation: Asatireis a literary work that uses humour, irony or ridicule to expose and criticize the flaws, vices or absurdities of individuals, institutions or society in general. It's often used to provoke thought or encourage change by pointing out what is wrong or foolish.

text: In ''the wretched beggar cleaned his nails with dry saliva'' the device used is
explanation: Anoxymoronis a figure of speech in which two contradictory or opposite words or ideas are combined to create a paradoxical effect. In this case, "dry" and "saliva" are placed side by side. The juxtaposition of such contrasting images is characteristic of an oxymoron.

text: A symbolic representation of ideas, actions and situations in a work of art is a/an
explanation:
Anallegoryis a symbolic representation where characters, events or settings in a work of art represent abstract ideas, moral qualities or political or historical situations. Allegories are used to convey complex ideas or lessons through symbolism.
For example, inAnimal Farmby George Orwell, the animals on the farm symbolise different groups in society and political systems.

text: ''The cell is a cruel place; sometimes a haven'', illustrates the use of
explanation: Aparadoxis a statement that seems contradictory or self-opposing, yet it may contain a truth. In this case, "The cell is a cruel place; sometimes a haven" presents two opposite ideas—cruelty and haven—but suggests that the cell can embody both qualities, depending on the situation. This creates a paradox.

text: An elegy is a poem that usually expresses a state of
explanation: Anelegyis a type of poem that expresses sorrow or grief, especially for someone who has passed away. It reflects on loss and the feelings associated with it.

text: In ''I am so famished, I can devour a whole cow'', the device used is
explanation: Hyperboleis an exaggerated statement or claim not meant to be taken literally. In this case, "I can devour a whole cow" is an exaggeration used to emphasise how hungry the speaker is.

text: The repetition of initial consonant sounds in poetry is
explanation: Alliterationrefers to the repetition of the initial consonant sounds in words close to each other, often used in poetry for rhythm or emphasis. For example, in the phrase "Peter Piper picked a peck of pickled peppers," the "p" sound is repeated.

text: ''Here comes the princess. Now heaven walks on earth'', illustrates the use of
explanation: In this sentence, "heaven walks on earth" is ametaphor, as it compares the princess to heaven, suggests that she is divine or heavenly in a figurative sense. The comparison does not use "like" or "as," which distinguishes it as a metaphor.

text: In the line '' I walk upon the thorns of life'', the metre is
explanation:
The line "I walk upon the thorns of life" follows aniambicmeter, as it has a pattern of alternating unstressed and stressed syllables. The stress pattern goes like this:
Iwalk(unstressed, stressed)upon (unstressed, stressed)thethorns(unstressed, stressed)oflife(unstressed, stressed)
Each pair of syllables (foot) starts with an unstressed syllable followed by a stressed one, which characterizesiambicmeter.

text: An ode is usually a poem written for
explanation: Anodeis a type of poem that is written to express strong feelings of praise or celebration, directed at a particular person, event or object. It usually celebrates its subject with formal language and a dignified tone.

text: The passage is
explanation: The passage is an expository article that discusses the killing of whales. It highlights the inhumane nature of their death and the unnecessary practice given that substitutes for whale products exist. It aims to expose the reader to the unethical and unnecessary aspects of the whaling industry.

text: The theme of the passage is (that)

options.A: whales are a menace to mankind
options.B: the killing of whale is unnecessary

explanation: The passage emphasises that the killing of whales is not only inhumane but also unnecessary as there are alternatives to the products made from whale carcasses.

text: The underlined expression suggests that the writer

options.A: has an aversion for the process

explanation: The expression describing the killing of the whale as "inhumane" and the use of words like "suffering" and "gentle-giant" suggests that the writer finds the process objectionable and has a strong negative feeling towards it.

text: ''.....gentle giant'' conveys the picture of being
explanation: The phrase "gentle giant" conveys an image of something large and powerful, but kind and not aggressive. It suggests that the whale, despite its size, is not dangerous but rather calm and docile.

text: ''...like a steer in a slaughterhouse'' is an example of
explanation: The phrase "like a steer in a slaughterhouse" is a simile because it compares the whale's situation to that of a steer using the word "like." Similes use "like" or "as" to make comparisons between two different things.

text: The poetic device used in the first line is
explanation: In the first line, "Thou art the judge of man," the speaker is directly addressing someone or something as though it were present, which is characteristic ofapostrophe. Apostrophe is a rhetorical device in which the speaker addresses an absent person, an abstract idea, or a thing as if it were present and capable of responding.

text: The last line of each stanza illustrates
explanation: The last line of each stanza ("You are the patient Judge") is repeated, which is characteristic of arefrain. A refrain is a line or group of lines that is repeated at intervals throughout a poem or song usually at the end of each stanza.

text: The dominant device used in stanza three is
explanation: In stanza three, time is described as if it has human qualities: "Time smiles and laughs / He frowns his face and consults with fate." This gives human traits to the concept of time, which is an example ofpersonification.

text: The poem is about
explanation: The poem portraystimeas a judge, observing and judging the actions, plans and behaviours of mankind. Time is depicted as a force that reveals people's follies, and it is patient in its judgment, as it waits and unfolds.

text: The extract teaches us to use time
explanation: The poem portrays time as a judge that reveals the consequences of human actions and decisions. It emphasises the importance of being patient and mindful of time, suggesting that nations and individuals often boast or make plans without considering the wisdom of time. Time ultimately shows the folly of those who do not use it wisely.

text: The speaker is
explanation: In Act 1, Scene 1 ofTwelfth Night, Viola, disguised as Cesario, expresses her longing and frustration about her unrequited love for Orsino. She wishes she could serve the lady (Olivia) and have her situation (her estate) be ripe for her to express her true feelings.

text: ''That lady'' refers to
explanation: Viola, speaking as Cesario, is expressing her desire to serve Olivia, whom she is secretly in love with. Olivia is the primary object of Orsino’s affection in the play, and Viola (as Cesario) wishes she could win her heart.

text: The speaker is addressing

options.A: a sea captain, friend to Sebastian
options.B: a sea captain, friend to Viola

explanation: InTwelfth Night, Viola is speaking to the sea captain who helped her after the shipwreck and has been assisting her while she disguises herself as Cesario. She shares her feelings and thoughts with him in several instances, and the lines in question are part of her conversation with the captain.

text: The word ''delivered'' in line 2 means
explanation: Viola is expressing her wish that she could serve Olivia and be in a situation where she would not have to reveal her true feelings (or "estate") to the world until the right moment when she has fully prepared herself.

text: Speaker A is
explanation: In this scene fromTwelfth Night(Act 2, Scene V), Sir Toby Belch is engaging in witty, playful banter with others. The conversation involves him mocking others and making light of the situation. The dialogue reflects Sir Toby's characteristic humour and mischievous nature.

text: Speaker B is
explanation: In this scene, Sir Andrew Aguecheek is engaging in a playful dialogue with Sir Toby Belch. Both characters are involved in a jesting conversation where they humorously agree to each other's remarks. Sir Andrew is often portrayed as a foolish and naive character, which is reflected in his responses in this exchange.

text: Speaker A and B are discussing
explanation: In Act 2, Scene V ofTwelfth Night, Sir Toby Belch and Sir Andrew Aguecheek are discussing Maria. They are amused by the idea of marrying her for her wit and cleverness. Maria is an intelligent and resourceful servant, and she plays a central role in the scheme to trick Malvolio.

text: The conversation reveals that Speaker B is
explanation: Throughout the exchange, Sir Andrew simply agrees with whatever Sir Toby says without offering much of his own opinion or thought. His responses are quick and submissive, showing that he is easily influenced by Sir Toby's remarks, which highlights his gullibility and lack of independent thinking.

text: Speaker A is
explanation: In Act 3, Scene 1 ofTwelfth Night, Viola (disguised as Cesario) is speaking to Feste, the clown. Viola's dialogue here involves asking Feste whether he makes a living through his labour or by some other means. Feste's witty response about living "by the church" is part of the playful exchange between the characters.

text: Speaker B is
explanation: In this extract from Act 3, Scene 1 ofTwelfth Night, Feste, known for his wit and wordplay, is responding humorously to Viola's question. His clever remark about living "by the church" demonstrates his characteristic play on words and his ability to turn a simple question into a comedic moment.

text: The phrase ''live by'' as used in the extract is an example of
explanation: A pun is a play on words that exploits multiple meanings or similar sounds for humorous or rhetorical effect. In this case, Feste humorously twists the meaning of "live by" to imply both making a living (earning an income) and physically living near the church.

text: Speakers A and B are
explanation: This exchange occurs in Act 3, Scene 1 ofTwelfth Night, when Viola (disguised as Cesario) visits Olivia's estate. The conversation takes place in a part of Olivia's property, which is typically referred to as her garden or courtyard.

text: Speaker A is
explanation: In this scene from Act 4, Scene 2 ofTwelfth Night, Feste is disguised as "Sir Topas," a fictional curate, and is mockingly addressing Malvolio, who is locked away. He humorously pretends to engage in a philosophical and moral debate with Malvolio, adding to the comedic elements of the play.

text: The person addressed is
explanation: In Act 4, Scene 2 ofTwelfth Night, Feste (disguised as Sir Topas) is speaking to Malvolio, who is imprisoned in a dark room as part of a prank. Malvolio responds to Feste's mockery, claiming that the room is "as dark as hell."

text: Speaker A, wants the audience to believe that he is
explanation: In this scene, Feste pretends to treat Malvolio as though he is insane, mocking him under the guise of being a wise and pious curate. This is part of the ongoing prank orchestrated against Malvolio, where the other characters try to convince him that he has lost his sanity.

text: Sir Topas is expected to be a
explanation: In Act 4, Scene 2 ofTwelfth Night, Feste disguises himself as "Sir Topas," a fictional clergyman (parson) brought in to "examine" Malvolio. This is part of the comedic ploy to convince Malvolio that he is mad. The name "Sir Topas" and the character's behaviour parody the role of a parson.

text: The speaker is
explanation: In this passage fromTwelfth Night(Act 5, Scene 1),Sebastianis speaking toOlivia. The context is that Olivia has just married Sebastian, thinking he was Cesario (Viola in disguise). Sebastian is apologizing for having hurt her kinsman (who was Sir Toby) during the earlier part of the scene. He refers to “the brother of my blood” to explain his actions and also acknowledges the vows he and Olivia made, which refers to their recent marriage.

text: .......''the brother o my blood'' implies he is
explanation: In the phrase"the brother of my blood,"the speaker (Orsino) is referring to hisownbrother, implying that if it had been his own brother, he would have had to act in the same way (with wit and safety). The use of "my" makes it clear that he is talking about hisownbrother, not someone else's.

text: ''the vows'' refers to
explanation: In this passage fromTwelfth Night, when Sebastian refers to "the vows we made each other but so late ago," he is talking about the vows he and Olivia recently made during their marriage.

text: The speaker is replied by
explanation: The speaker is replied by Orsino.
